page.title: 08WILDLIFE AT HADHAM HALL
page.content: The children at the school provide an abundance of food for wild birds in the form of discarded food packets. As a result there a large numbers of Rooks, Starlings, Thrushes and especially Sparrows. Many of these nest in buildings on the estate although the Rooks come from a nearby copse. The three ponds, formerly the moat, also encourage birdlife in the form of Coots, Moorhens and several Ducks. These nest on the ponds and produce a number of chicks each year. The ponds are also stocked with a variety of fish, especially Carp. There are a number of reptiles including Frogs and Toads a number of which have to be rescued from the Swimming Pool in the summer. On the playing fields there a number of Rabbits. Based on a survey by 1H.
